'''Sir [[Winston Churchill|Winston Leonard Spencer-Churchill]]''', KG, OM, CH, TD, PC, DL, FRS, RA received numerous '''honours and awards''' throughout his career as a [[British Army]] officer, [[politician|statesman]] and author.
Perhaps the highest of these was the [[funeral of Winston Churchill|state funeral]] held at [[St Paul's Cathedral]], after his body had [[Lying in state#United Kingdom|lain in state]] for three days in [[Westminster Hall]],<ref>Picknett, et al., p. 252.</ref> an honour rarely granted to anyone other than a British monarch or consort. The funeral also saw one of the largest assemblages of statesmen in the world.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gould |first=Peter |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4421081.stm |title=Europe | Holding history's largest funeral |work=BBC News |date=8 April 2005 |accessdate=9 August 2009}}</ref>
Throughout his life, Churchill also accumulated other honours and awards. He was awarded 37 other orders and [[medals]] between 1885 and 1964. Of the orders, decorations and medals Churchill received, 20 were awarded by the United Kingdom, three by France, two each by [[Belgium]], [[Denmark]], [[Luxembourg]] and [[Kingdom of Spain|Spain]], and one each by the [[Czech Republic]], [[Egypt]], [[Estonia]], [[Kingdom of Libya|Libya]], [[Nepal]], the Netherlands, [[Norway]], and the [[United States]]. Ten were awarded for active service as an Army officer in [[Cuba]], India, Egypt, [[South Africa]], the United Kingdom, France, and Belgium. The greater number of awards were given in recognition of his service as a minister of the British government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winstonchurchill.org/learn/biography/the-soldier/orders-decorations-and-medals|title=The Life of Churchill|publisher=}}</ref>
==Coat of arms== [[File:Coat of Arms of Winston Churchill as a Gentleman.svg|thumb|right|Coat of Arms of Winston Churchill as a Gentleman]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Winston Churchill.svg|thumb|right|Coat of arms of Sir Winston Spencer-Churchill]] Churchill was not a [[peerage|peer]], never held a title of nobility, and remained a [[commoner]] all his life. As the grandson of [[John Spencer-Churchill, 7th Duke of Marlborough|7th Duke of Marlborough]], he bore the [[Quartering (heraldry)|quartered]] coat of arms of the [[Spencer family|Spencer]] and Churchill families. Paul Courtenay observes that "It would be normal in these circumstances for the paternal arms (Spencer) to take precedence over the maternal (Churchill), but because the Marlborough dukedom was senior to the Sunderland earldom, the procedure was reversed in this case." In 1817 an [[augmentation of honour]] was granted commemorating the [[Battle of Blenheim|victory of Blenheim]] by the 1st Duke.<ref name="Courtenay ">Paul Courtenay, The Armorial Bearings of Sir Winston Churchill [http://www.winstonchurchill.org/learn/reference/armorial-bearings-of-wsc The Armorial Bearings of Sir Winston Churchill] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130718222952/http://www.winstonchurchill.org/learn/reference/armorial-bearings-of-wsc |date=18 July 2013 }} (accessed 20 July 2013).</ref>
As Churchill's father, [[Lord Randolph Churchill]], was the surviving second son of the 7th Duke of Marlborough, his arms should have been differenced, by strict heraldic rules, with a [[Cadency|mark of cadency]]. Traditionally, this would have been a heraldic crescent. Those differenced arms would have been inherited by Winston Churchill. This never seems to have been used by Lord Randolph or Winston. As arms are used to differentiate two bearers, there doesn't seem to have been any confusion between Churchill's arms as a gentleman with many decorations and later Knight of the Garter, those of his brother as a plain gentleman, and his cousin, the Duke of Marlborough, which were adorned with the insignia of a duke. As a Knight of the Garter, Churchill was also entitled to supporters in his achievement. But, he never seems to have got around to applying for them.<ref>Paul Courtenay, The Armorial Bearings of Sir Winston Churchill [https://www.winstonchurchill.org/resources/reference/the-armorial-bearings-of-sir-winston-churchill/ The Armorial Bearings of Sir Winston Churchill {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130718222952/http://www.winstonchurchill.org/learn/reference/armorial-bearings-of-wsc |date=18 July 2013 }} (accessed 02 February 2018).</ref>
The resulting heraldic achievement is: ''quarterly 1st and 4th, Sable a lion rampant Argent on a canton of the second a cross Gules ([[Duke of Marlborough (title)#Coats of arms|Churchill]]); 2nd and 3rd, quarterly Argent and Gules, in the second and third quarters a fret Or, over all on a bend Sable three escallops of the first ([[Spencer family#Coat of arms|Spencer]]); in chief, on an escutcheon Argent a cross Gules surmounted by an inescutcheon Azure charged with three [[fleurs-de-lys]] Or''.<ref name="Courtenay"/>
When he became a [[Order of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]] in 1953, his arms were encircled by the garter of the order, and at the same time the [[Helmet (heraldry)|helms]] was made open, which is the mark of a knight. His motto was that of the Dukes of Marlborough, ''Fiel pero desdichado'' (Spanish for "Faithful but unfortunate").<ref name="Robson, Thomas 1830, p 401">Robson, Thomas, ''The British Herald, or Cabinet of Armorial Bearings of the Nobility & Gentry of Great Britain & Ireland'', Volume I, Turner & Marwood, Sunderland, 1830, p. 401 (CHU-CLA).</ref>
==Honorary citizen== On 9 April 1963, [[President of the United States|United States President]] [[John F. Kennedy]], acting under authorization granted by an Act of Congress, proclaimed Churchill the first [[honorary citizen of the United States]]. Churchill was physically incapable of attending the [[White House]] ceremony, so his son and grandson accepted the award for him.<ref name="plumpton1988summer">{{cite journal|last=Plumpton|first=John|title=A Son of America Though a Subject of Britain|journal=Finest Hour|date=Summer 1988|issue=60|url=http://www.winstonchurchill.org/learn/biography/redux/churchill-honored-with-us-citizenship}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEcGEyB2MA0|title=April 9, 1963 - President John F. Kennedy declares Winston Churchill an honorary citizen of the USA|first=|last=HelmerReenberg|date=29 May 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Proposed dukedom== In 1955, after retiring as Prime Minister, Churchill was offered elevation to the peerage in the rank of [[duke]]. By custom, [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom#Retirement honours|Prime Ministers retiring]] from the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|Commons]] were usually offered [[earldom]]s, so the dukedom was a sign of special honour. One title that was considered was ''Duke of London'', a city whose name had never been used in a peerage title. Churchill had represented divisions of three different counties in Parliament, and his home, [[Chartwell]], was in a fourth, so the city in which he had spent most of his time during fifty years in politics was seen as a suitable choice.<ref name="ramsden2002">{{cite book | title=Man of the Century: Winston Churchill and His Legend Since 1945 | publisher=Columbia University Press | author=Ramsden, John | year=2002 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fhiI_jKRM0gC&lpg=PA113&ots=ZNyVdMZnYE&pg=PA113#v=onepage&f=false | pages=113, 597 | isbn=9780231131063}}</ref> Since 1900, only members of the British royal family have been made dukes, so the offer was exceptional.<ref name=autogenerated1>The Orders, Decorations and Medals of Sir Winston Churchill by Douglas Russell</ref>
Churchill considered accepting the offer of a dukedom but eventually declined it; the lifestyle of a duke would have been expensive, and accepting any peerage might have cut short a renewed career in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|Commons]] for his son [[Randolph Churchill|Randolph]] and in due course might also prevent one for his grandson [[Winston Churchill (1940–2010)|Winston]].{{r|ramsden2002}} (At the time there was no procedure for disclaiming a title; the procedure was first established by the [[Peerage Act 1963]]. Upon inheriting a peerage, either Randolph or Winston would immediately be unseated from the House of Commons.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winstonchurchill.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=398|title=Welcome to WinstonChurchill.org|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070207054857/http://www.winstonchurchill.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=398|archivedate=7 February 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the event, Randolph never sat in Parliament after losing his first and only seat there in 1945 and indeed was to die only three years after his father, so the dukedom would have had no effect on his career. Randolph's oldest son [[Winston Churchill (1940-2010)|Winston]] did serve in the Commons from 1970 until 1997, but by that time provision existed for disclaiming a hereditary peerage.
==Other honours== [[File:TNA INF3-3 Winston Churchill in RAF uniform 1939-1946.jpg|thumbnail|right|150px|Painting of Churchill in his air commodore's uniform]] [[File:Brooke - Churchill - Montgomery.jpg|thumbnail|right|150px|Churchill in his [[Trinity House]] uniform with Field Marshal Alan Brooke (left) and Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery, 1944]] In 1913, Churchill was appointed an ''Elder Brother'' of [[Trinity House]] as result of his appointment as [[First Lord of the Admiralty]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Churchill at Chartwell: Museums and Libraries Series|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0HmoBQAAQBAJ|publisher = Elsevier|date = 15 May 2014|isbn = 9781483161365|language = en|first = Robin|last = Fedden}}</ref>
On 4 April 1939, Churchill was made an [[Honorary Air Commodore]] of [[No. 615 Squadron RAF|No. 615 (County of Surrey) Squadron]] ("Churchill's Own") in the [[Auxiliary Air Force]].<ref name="TimesChurchillUniform">{{cite news|title=Questions Answered: Winston Churchill in uniform and Ralph or Rafe|url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/court_and_social/article4742261.ece |accessdate=14 June 2010|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date = 13 September 2008}}</ref> In March 1943, the [[Air Council]] awarded Churchill honorary [[aircrew brevet|wings]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /> He retained the appointment until 11 March 1957 when 615 Squadron was disbanded. He did however continue to hold the rank of Honorary Air Commodore.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=41083 |date=28 May 1957 |page=3227 |supp=y }}</ref> He frequently wore his uniform as an Air Commodore during World War II.
He was the [[Colonel in Chief]] of the [[4th Queen's Own Hussars]] (his old regiment) and after its amalgamation, the first Colonel in Chief of the [[Queen's Royal Irish Hussars]] which he held until his death in 1965. He was also Colonel in Chief of the [[Queen's Own Oxfordshire Hussars]].{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
From 1941 to his death, he was the [[Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports]], a ceremonial office. In 1941 [[Governor General of Canada|Canadian Governor General]] [[Alexander Cambridge, 1st Earl of Athlone|Alexander Cambridge, Earl of Athlone]], swore him into the [[Queen's Privy Council for Canada|King's Privy Council for Canada]]. Although this allowed him to use the honorific title ''[[The Honourable]]'' and the post-nominal letters ''PC'', both of these were trumped by his membership in the Imperial Privy Council which allowed him the use of ''[[The Right Honourable]]''.<ref name= autogenerated1 /> He was also appointed Grand Seigneur of the Hudson's Bay Company in December 1955.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
In 1945, he was mentioned by [[Halvdan Koht]] among seven candidates that were qualified for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]]. However, he did not explicitly nominate any of them. Actually he nominated [[Cordell Hull]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://nobelprize.org/nomination/peace/nomination.php?action=show&showid=3319 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130904010737/http://www.nobelprize.org/nomination/peace/nomination.php?action=show&showid=3319 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 4 September 2013 | accessdate = 14 May 2010 | title = Record from The Nomination Database for the Nobel Prize in Peace, 1901–1956 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}}</ref>
Churchill held the office of [[Deputy Lieutenant]] (DL) of [[Kent]] in 1949.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lundy |first=Darryl |url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p10620.htm#i106196 |title= Biography Rt. Hon. Sir Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill |publisher=The Peerage}}{{Unreliable source?|failed=y |date=February 2013}}<!--Lundy is not a reliable source so cite Lundy's reliable source See [[WP:SAYWHEREYOUREADIT]]--> – website thePeerage.com</ref>
In 1953, he was awarded two major honours: he was invested as a [[Order of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]] (becoming Sir Winston Churchill, KG) and he was awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel Prize for Literature]] ''"for his mastery of historical and biographical description as well as for brilliant oratory in defending exalted human values".''<ref>{{cite web|url= http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1953/ |title=Literature 1953 |publisher=Nobelprize.org |date= |accessdate=9 August 2009}}</ref>
He was Chancellor of the [[University of Bristol]] as well as in 1959, ''[[Father of the House]]'', the MP with the longest continuous service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moreorless.au.com/heroes/churchill.html |title=Winston Churchill hero file |publisher=More or Less |location=AU |date= |accessdate=9 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016104226/http://www.moreorless.au.com/heroes/churchill.html |archivedate=16 October 2009 |df= }}</ref>
In 1956, Churchill received the [[Karlspreis]] (known in English as the Charlemagne Award), an award by the German city of [[Aachen]] to those who most contribute to the European idea, and European peace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.karlspreis.de/index.php?id=12&doc=7 |title=Internationaler Karlspreis zu Aachen – Detail |publisher=Karlspreis | location = DE |date= |accessdate=9 August 2009 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927001140/http://www.karlspreis.de/index.php?id=12&doc=7 |archivedate = 27 September 2007}}</ref>
In 1961 the [[Chartered Institute of Building]]<ref>[[Chartered Institute of Building|CIOB]]</ref> named Churchill as an Honorary Fellow for his services and passion for the construction industry.
In 1964, [[Civitan International]] presented Churchill its first World Citizenship Award for service to the world community.<ref>{{cite book |last= Armbrester |first= Margaret E. |title= The Civitan Story |year= 1992 |publisher= Ebsco Media |location= Birmingham, AL |pages= 96–97 }}</ref>
Churchill was also appointed a [[Kentucky Colonel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kycolonels.org/index.cgi?id=54 |title=Colonels web site |publisher=Kycolonels.org |date= |accessdate=9 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625033818/http://kycolonels.org/index.cgi?id=54 |archivedate=25 June 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sos.ky.gov/executive/kentuckycolonels.htm |title=Kentucky: Secretary of State – Kentucky Colonels |publisher=Sos.ky.gov |date=26 October 2006 |accessdate=9 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709034200/http://sos.ky.gov/executive/kentuckycolonels.htm |archivedate=9 July 2009 |df= }}</ref>
When Churchill was 88 he was asked by the [[Duke of Edinburgh]] how he would like to be remembered. He replied with a scholarship like the [[Rhodes scholarship]] but for the wider masses. After his death, the [[Winston Churchill Memorial Trust]] was established in the United Kingdom and Australia. A Churchill Trust Memorial Day was held in Australia, raising A$4.3 million. Since that time the Churchill Trust in Australia has supported over 3,000 scholarship recipients in a diverse variety of fields, where merit, either on the basis of past experience, or potential, and the propensity to contribute to the community have been the only criteria.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
==Namesakes== [[File:USS Winston S. Churchill (DDG 81) English Channel.jpg|thumbnail|left|150px|USS ''Winston S. Churchill'']] [[File:Pol Roger 1973 UK and non-UK label.jpg|thumb|right|On the right, the black border used by Pol Roger on bottles shipped to the UK from 1965 to 1990.]]
The [[Winston Churchill Range]] in the [[Canadian Rockies]] was named in his honour.
One of four specially made sets of [[false teeth]], designed to retain Churchill's distinctive style of speech, which Churchill wore throughout his life, is now kept in the Hunterian Museum at the [[Royal College of Surgeons of England]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Teeth That Saved The World? — The Royal College of Surgeons of England|url=http://www.rcseng.ac.uk/museums/exhibitions/churchill|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070422042229/http://www.rcseng.ac.uk/museums/exhibitions/churchill|archivedate=22 April 2007|date=29 November 2005}}</ref>
Two [[Royal Navy]] warships have been named HMS ''Churchill'': the destroyer {{USS|Herndon|DD-198|6}} (I45) (1940–1944) and the submarine {{HMS|Churchill|S46|6}} (1970–1991).
On 10 March 2001, the ''[[Arleigh Burke class destroyer|Arleigh Burke]]''-class destroyer {{USS|Winston S. Churchill|DDG-81}} was commissioned into the [[United States Navy]]. The launch and christening of the ship two years earlier was co-sponsored by Churchill's daughter, [[Mary Soames, Baroness Soames|Lady Soames]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.churchill.navy.mil/|title=Home – USS W.S. Churchill |publisher=Churchill.navy.mil |date= |accessdate=9 August 2009}}</ref>
In addition, the Danish [[DFDS]] line named a car ferry ''[[MS Winston Churchill|Winston Churchill]]'' and The Corporation of Trinity House named one of their lighthouse tenders similarly. A sail training ship was named ''Sir Winston Churchill''.
In September 1947, the [[Southern Railway (Great Britain)|Southern Railway]] named a [[SR West Country and Battle of Britain classes|Battle of Britain class]] steam locomotive [[SR Battle of Britain class 21C151 Winston Churchill|No. 21C151]] after him. Churchill was offered the opportunity to perform the naming ceremony, but he declined. The locomotive was later used to pull his funeral train, and is now preserved in the [[National Railway Museum]], York.
He appeared on the 1965 [[Crown (British coin)|crown]], the first commoner to be placed on a British coin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.24carat.co.uk/1965crownframe.html |title=1965 Churchill Crown |publisher=24carat.co.uk |date= |accessdate=9 August 2009}}</ref> He made another appearance on a crown issued in 2010 to honour the 70th anniversary of his Premiership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.coinupdate.com/winston-churchill-crown-from-the-british-royal-mint-0375/ |title=Winston Churchill £5 Crown from the British Royal Mint |publisher=CoinUpdate.com |date= |accessdate=23 July 2010}}</ref>
[[Pol Roger]]'s [[prestige cuvée]] Champagne, ''Cuvée Sir Winston Churchill'', is named after him. The first vintage, 1975, was launched in 1984 at [[Blenheim Palace]]. The name was accepted by his heirs as Churchill was a faithful customer of Pol Roger. Following Churchill's death in 1965, Pol Roger added a black border to the label on bottles shipped to the UK as a sign of mourning. This was not lifted until 1990.<ref>[http://www.polroger.co.uk/champagne_churchill.php Pol Roger UK: Sir Winston Churchill] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714202134/http://www.polroger.co.uk/champagne_churchill.php |date=14 July 2007 }}, accessed 12 July 2010</ref>
The [[Churchill tank]], or Infantry Tank Mk IV; was a British Second World War tank named after Churchill, who was Prime Minister at the time of its design.<ref>{{cite web|author=Chris Shillito |url=http://www.armourinfocus.co.uk/a22/ |title=The Churchill Tank |publisher=Armourinfocus.co.uk |date= |accessdate=9 August 2009}}</ref>
The ''Julieta'' (7" × 47), a size of [[cigar]], is also commonly known as a Churchill.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
The Churchill Park<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Churchillparken&oldid=814172517|title=Churchillparken|date=7 December 2017|publisher=|via=Wikipedia}}</ref> ([[Danish language|Danish]]: Churchillparken) located in central [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]], is name after Churchill in commemoration of Churchill and the British help to Denmark in the liberation of Denmark during [[World War II]].
==Polls== Churchill has been included in numerous polls, mostly connected with greatness. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' named him its [[Time Person of the Year|Man of the Year]] for 1940,<ref name="time19410106">{{cite news|title=GREAT BRITAIN: Man of the Year|url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,765143,00.html|accessdate=26 December 2010|newspaper=Time|date=6 January 1941}}</ref> and "Man of the Half-Century" in 1949.<ref name="time19500102">{{cite news|title=Winston Churchill, Man of the Year|url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19500102,00.html|accessdate=26 December 2010|newspaper=Time|date=2 January 1950}}</ref> A BBC survey, of January 2000, saw Churchill voted the greatest British prime minister of the 20th century. In 2002, BBC TV viewers and web site users voted him the greatest Briton of all time in a ten-part series called [[Great Britons]], a poll attracting almost two million votes.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060514084331/http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/programmes/greatbritons.shtml BBC – Great Britons<!-- Bot generated title -->].</ref>
== Buildings, highways, statues and geographic features == [[File:Winston Churchill statue in London.jpg|thumb|210px|A statue of Sir [[Winston Churchill]] in Parliament Square]] Many statues have been created in likeness and in honour of Churchill. Numerous buildings and squares have also been named in his honour. The most prominent example of a statue of Churchill is the [[Statue of Winston Churchill, Parliament Square|official statue]] commissioned by the government and created by [[Ivor Roberts-Jones]] which now stands in [[Parliament Square]]. It was unveiled by Churchill's widow, [[Clementine Churchill, Baroness Spencer-Churchill|Lady Churchill]], on 1 November 1973, and was [[Listed building|Grade II listed]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/churchill-statue-had-the-look-of-mussolini-578159.html |title=Churchill statue 'had the look of Mussolini'|accessdate=18 August 2011 |author= Sherna Noah|date=1 January 2004|work=[[The Independent]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.london.gov.uk/parliamentsquare/about/churchill.jsp|title=Sir Winston Churchill|accessdate=18 August 2011|author=|date=|publisher=Greater London Authority|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712135021/http://www.london.gov.uk/parliamentsquare/about/churchill.jsp|archivedate=12 July 2011|df=}}</ref> Another Roberts-Jones statue of Churchill displaying the V sign<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WM3X81_Winston_Churchill_New_Orleans_LA|title=Winston Churchill - New Orleans, LA - Statues of Historic Figures on Waymarking.com|publisher=}}</ref> is prominently placed in New Orleans (1977). In addition several other statues have also been made, including a bronze [[bust of Winston Churchill (Epstein)|bust of Winston Churchill]] by [[Jacob Epstein]] (1947), several statues by [[David McFall]] at [[Woodford, London|Woodford]] (1959), [[William McVey]] outside the British embassy in [[Washington, D.C.]] (1966), [[Franta Belsky]] at [[Fulton, Missouri]] (1969), at least three from [[Oscar Nemon]]: one on the front lawn of the [[Halifax Public Libraries|Halifax Public Library]] branch on [[Spring Garden Road]], [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]] (1980); one in the [[British House of Commons]] (1969); a bust of his head along with that of [[Franklin Roosevelt]] commemorating the [[Quebec Conference, 1943]] next to Port St. Louis in [[Quebec City]] (1998); and one in [[Nathan Phillips Square]] outside of [[Toronto City Hall]] (1977), and [[Jean Cardot]] beside the [[Petit Palais]] in Paris (1998).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/32413?docPos=3|title=Churchill, Sir Winston Leonard Spencer (1874–1965), prime minister - Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=}}</ref> A statue of Churchill and [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Roosevelt]], sculpted by [[Lawrence Holofcener]] is located in [[New Bond Street]], London.
After Churchill was declared the greatest Briton of all time in the BBC poll and television series [[Great Britons]] (see above), a statue was erected in his honour and now stands at the BBC television studios. Churchill is also memorialised by many statues and a public square in [[New York City|New York]], in recognition of his life, and also because his mother was from New York. His maternal family is also memorialised in streets, parks, and neighbourhoods throughout the city. [[File:WinstonChurchillHalfaxNovaScotia.JPG|thumb|left|Statue in [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax, Nova Scotia]] by [[Oscar Nemon]]]] The national and Commonwealth memorial to Churchill is [[Churchill College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]], which was founded in 1958 and opened in 1960. It is also home to the Churchill Archives Centre, which holds the papers of Sir Winston Churchill and over 570 collections of personal papers and archives documenting the history of the Churchill era and after.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chu.cam.ac.uk/archives/ |title=Churchill College : Churchill Archives Centre |publisher=Chu.cam.ac.uk |date=6 March 2009 |accessdate=9 August 2009}}</ref>
Many schools have been named after him:{{Further|Winston Churchill High School (disambiguation)|Sir Winston Churchill Secondary School (disambiguation)}}
Ten schools in Canada are named in his honour: one each in [[Vancouver]], [[Winnipeg]], [[Thunder Bay]], [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]], [[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]], [[St. Catharines]], [[Lethbridge]], [[Calgary]], [[Toronto]] ([[Scarborough, Toronto|Scarborough]]) and [[Ottawa]]. Churchill Auditorium at the [[Technion]] is named after him.
At least four American high schools carry his name; these are located in [[Potomac, Maryland]]; [[Livonia, Michigan]]; [[Eugene, Oregon]] and [[San Antonio, Texas]].
In London, [[One Churchill Place|Churchill Place]] is one of the main squares in [[Canary Wharf]]. Winston Churchill Avenue is a major road in [[Portsmouth]]. [[Basingstoke]] and [[Salford, Greater Manchester|Salford]] both have roads called Churchill Way.
[[File:Churchill Prague embassy 4691.JPG|thumb|A bust of Churchill close to the [[Embassy of the United Kingdom, Prague|British Embassy in Prague]]]] The city of [[Edmonton|Edmonton, Alberta]], Canada has a stop on the [[Edmonton LRT]] system and a public square named in his honour. [[Churchill Square (Edmonton)|Churchill Square]], is the main square in that city and was renovated in 2004 for the city's 100th anniversary of incorporation. There are several other squares named after him, including one in [[Churchill Square (Brighton and Hove)|Brighton]], England and one in [[Churchill Square (St. John's)|Newfoundland]]. The south end of Churchill Avenue in [[Ottawa]] was the site of the Churchill Arms Motor Hotel, which many residents of Ottawa remember for its three-storey exterior painting of the silhouette of Winston Churchill.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sale threatens future of Churchill Arms|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19860401&id=C78yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b-8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4620,163431|accessdate=18 March 2014|newspaper=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|date=1 April 1986}}</ref> Churchill Avenue was itself renamed from Main Street after the Second World War. In [[St. Albert, Alberta]] Sir Winston Churchill Ave runs east to west through the city. [[Winston Churchill Boulevard]] in [[Mississauga]], [[Ontario]], Canada is also named in his honour.
[[Churchill National Park]] in Australia which was established on 12 February 1941 as the Dandenong National Park, was renamed in 1944 in his honour. The town of [[Churchill, Victoria]], [[Churchill Island]] and [[Churchill Island Marine National Park]] in [[Victoria, Australia]] were also named after him.
In Canada, [[Sir Winston Churchill Provincial Park]], [[Churchill Park, St. John's]] and [[Churchill Lake]] in [[Saskatchewan]] were all named after him.
A large [[Dock (maritime)|dock]] in the [[Port of Antwerp]] was named after him by [[Queen Elizabeth II]] at a ceremony in 1966.
Náměstí W. Churchilla (Winston Churchill Square) is located behind [[Praha hlavní nádraží|The Main Train Station]] in [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]].
In [[Gibraltar]] the main road connecting the border with Spain and the airport to the city centre is called [[Winston Churchill Avenue]].
[[Churchillparken]] in [[Copenhagen]], Denmark; [[Churchill Park, Glendowie]], New Zealand; [[Churchill Park (Lautoka)]], Fiji; and [[Energlyn and Churchill Park railway station]] in Wales are some other parks named in his honour.
In Norway streets in the cities of [[Trondheim]] and [[Tromsø]] are named in Winston Churchill's honour. Namely "Churchills vei"<ref>{{cite web|author=Norway Rd |url=https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=Churchill+NOrway&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=31.646818,86.572266&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Norway+Rd,+Pittsburgh,+Allegheny,+Pennsylvania+15221&ll=63.428912,10.486708&spn=0.004358,0.021136&z=16 |title=Churchill NOrway – Google Maps |publisher=Maps.google.com |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=14 June 2013}}</ref> in Jakobsli, Trondheim and "Winston Churchills vei" in Tromsø.
The Churchill occupying an entire block in [[New York City]]'s [[Midtown Manhattan]] neighborhood is a residential building named after him, and features his portrait in the lobby and rooftop pool (rare for NYC residences).<ref>http://streeteasy.com/building/the-churchill</ref> Many smaller, less significant streets and public buildings, particularly in the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand have been named in honour of Churchill.

[[Image:Hector Fix-Zamudio.jpg|thumb|Héctor Fix-Zamudio receiving the [[Belisario Domínguez Medal]] in 2002]] '''Héctor Fix-Zamudio''' (born 4 September 1924 in [[Mexico City]]) is a [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[jurist]]. ==Professional career== Fix-Zamudio studied law at the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] (UNAM), earning his bachelor's degree in 1956 and his doctorate (magna cum laude) in 1972. From 1945 to 1964 he held various positions within the [[Law of Mexico|Mexican judiciary]], culminating with a position as clerk to the [[Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation]]. In 1964 he accepted a full-time research position at the UNAM's Legal Research Institute ''(Instituto de Investigaciones Jurídicas)'', then known as the Institute of Comparative Law ''(Instituto de Derecho Comparado)''. He also served as the Institute's director from 1966 to 1978. In 1981 he was elected to the UNAM's Governing Board ''(Junta de Gobierno)'', serving until 1988.
In 1974 he was chosen as the first president of the [[Ibero-American Constitutional Law Institute]], a position he held until 2002 when he was named honorary president. He was elected to serve as a judge on the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights]] from 1987 to 1997, including two terms as its president. He served on the [[United Nations]] [[Sub-Commission on the Promotion and Protection of Human Rights|Sub-Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities]] from 1998 to 2001. He has been a member of the Consultative Council of the [[National Human Rights Commission (Mexico)|National Human Rights Commission]] since 1998.
==Awards and recognitions== On 23 October 1974 he was elected to the [[Colegio Nacional (Mexico)|Colegio Nacional]]. The awards he has won include the [[National Science and Arts Prize|National Prize for History, Social Science and Philosophy]] (1982), the [[National Jurisprudence Prize]], awarded in 1994 by the Mexican Bar Association (1994), and the [[Senate of Mexico|Senate]]'s [[Belisario Domínguez Medal|Belisario Domínguez Medal of Honour]] in 2002. In 1986 he was awarded the [[UNESCO Prize for Human Rights Education]], and he later served on the jury for that prize for four years from 1988 to 1991.
In recognition of his work in the field, the UNAM's Legal Research Institute currently awards the annual Héctor Fix-Zamudio International Prize for Legal Research.
==Publications== Fix-Zamudio has published 20 books on legal topics, including [[amparo (law)|amparo]], [[constitutional law]] and human rights.
==References== *[http://www.colegionacional.org.mx/SACSCMS/XStatic/colegionacional/template/content.aspx?se=curriculum&te=detallemiembro&mi=118 Héctor Fix-Zamudio] ([[Colegio Nacional (Mexico)|El Colegio Nacional]]) *[http://www.colegionacional.org.mx/SACSCMS/XStatic/colegionacional/docs/espanol/fix-zamudio.pdf Héctor Fix-Zamudio: Curriculum Vitae] *[http://www.juridicas.unam.mx/inst/evacad/premiohfz/ingles.htm Héctor Fix-Zamudio International Prize for Legal Research]

[[Image:IADB English Seal.jpg|thumb|right|150px|IADB Seal]] [[Image:Pink Palace DC.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Inter-American Defense Board headquarters in [[Washington, D.C.]]]] The '''Inter-American Defense Board''' ('''IADB''') is an international committee of nationally appointed defense officials who develop collaborative approaches on common defense and security issues facing countries in North, Central, and South America. The IADB provides technical advice and services to the [[Organization of American States]] (OAS).
The IADB was created in 1942 by foreign ministers of 21 states, in the middle of World War II. It is now the oldest existing defense organization in the world.
In March 2006, the OAS assumed formal authority over the IADB. As of that date, 27 of the 34 members of OAS were also members of the IADB.
== Inter-American Defense College== {{main|Inter-American Defense College}} The Board is made up of three main organs, one of which is the Inter-American Defense College (IADC). The IADC offers an eleven-month Master of Science for senior military, police and government officials that covers governmental systems, the current international environment, and the structure and function of the Inter-American system, and offers an opportunity to study broad-based defense and security issues affecting the Western Hemisphere and the world.
[http://www.iadc.edu official website]
== Inter-American Defense Board Medal == [[File:Inter America Defence Board Medal.jpg|thumb|right|100px|Inter-American Defense Board Medal]] {{main|Inter-American Defense Board Medal}}
The Inter-American Defense Board Medal is an [[international military decoration]]. It is awarded to any military officer, serving in a member nation of the OAS, who completes a tour of service with the IADB. The award is also presented to military personnel who serve on the staff of the IADB Chairman or Secretariat, and for those who complete instructor tours at the IADC.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051106025525/http://www.jid.org/en/ Official website] *[https://www.state.gov/p/wha/rls/rm/2006/q1/63141.htm "Remarks Regarding the Inter-American Defense Board"], Remarks by Ambassador John F. Maisto, U.S. Permanent Representative to the Organization of American States, to the Thirty-Second Special Session of the OAS General Assembly Considering the Juridical Link of the Inter-American Defense Board, March 15, 2006
{{int-org-stub}}

{{Infobox intersex rights | location_header = [[Colombia]] {{flagicon|Colombia}} | image = Colombia (orthographic projection).svg | caption = [[Colombia]] | prohibit_harmful = No | reparations = | discrimination_protections = No | access_identification = | equality_men_women = | mf_identification = Yes | third_identification = | marriage = Yes }} {{Intersex sidebar}} In 1999, the [[Constitutional Court of Colombia]] became the first court to consider the human rights implications of [[intersex medical interventions|medical interventions]] to alter the [[sex characteristics]] of [[intersex]] children. The Court restricted the age at which intersex children could be the subjects of surgical interventions.<ref name="isna" />
==History== {{further|Intersex in history}} The [[Constitutional Court of Colombia]] was the first court to consider the human rights implications of [[intersex medical interventions]], in a case that restricted the age at which intersex children could be the subjects of surgical interventions.<ref name="isna" />
In April 2018, Latin American and Caribbean intersex activists published the San José de Costa Rica statement, defining local demands.<ref>{{Cite web| last = Participants at the Latin American and Caribbean Regional Conference of Intersex Persons| title = San José de Costa Rica Statement| work = [[Brújula Intersexual]]| accessdate = 2018-09-05| date = April 13, 2018| url = https://brujulaintersexual.org/2018/04/13/san-jose-de-costa-rica-statement/}}</ref>
== Physical integrity and bodily autonomy == [[File:Protection of intersex children from harmful practices.svg|thumb|right|260px| {{legend|#002255|Legal prohibition of non-consensual [[Intersex medical interventions|medical interventions]]}} {{legend|#0066FF|Regulatory suspension of non-consensual medical interventions}}]] {{further|Intersex human rights|Intersex medical interventions}} [[File:Inclusion of sex characteristics in anti-discrimination law.svg|thumb|right|260px| {{legend|#002255|Explicit protection from [[Discrimination against intersex people|discrimination]] on grounds of [[sex characteristics]]}} {{legend|#0066FF|Explicit protection on grounds of intersex status}} {{legend|#9FCFFF|Explicit protection on grounds of intersex within attribute of sex}}]] Colombia does not prohibit harmful practices on children, but they are regulated through a series of decisions made by the [[Constitutional Court of Colombia]] relating to the bodily autonomy of infants and children, including those with intersex conditions.<ref name="icj" />
=== Sentencia T-477/95 === In Sentencia T-477/95, the Court considered the case of YY, a non-intersex teenage boy who had been raised a girl after an accidental castration and subsequent feminizing genital surgeries. He took the case after learning of his medical history. The Court ruled that the teenager’s right to identity had been violated, and that the sex of a child could not be altered without the child’s informed consent.<ref name = "icj" /><ref name="White2013" />
=== Sentencia SU-337/99 === In Sentencia SU-337/99, of May 12, 1999, the Court varied the earlier decision on informed consent for genital surgeries in children. The Court ruled in the case of XX, an 8-year old with ambiguous genitalia, [[androgen insensitivity syndrome|androgen insensitivity]] and XY chromosomes, raised as a girl. Doctors recommended [[intersex medical interventions|feminizing surgeries]], including a [[gonadectomy]], [[vaginoplasty]] and [[clitoroplasty]] before puberty, but the hospital would not proceed without the consent of the Colombian Institute of Family Welfare and the Office of the Public Advocate (Defensor del Pueblo de la Seccional del Departamento XX). The mother brought a case against Institute and Office of the Public Advocate, seeking to provide substitute consent. The mother argued that “the capacity to decide, it would be too late and would prevent normal psychological, physical, and social development”.<ref name = "icj337" />
The Court refused the mother’s claim. It questioned the urgency of the case, argued by medical teams. Civil rights advocates and a minority of doctors favored deferring treatment due to lack of evidence and the irreversible nature of the proposed interventions. The Court observed that advocates of surgery were more numerous than opponents, alternatives to surgery were not entirely feasible, and surgeries had improved, “making it less likely that sexual sensitivity would be destroyed; and the medical community was improving communication with parents”.<ref name = "icj337" /> However, some doctors refused to respond to criticisms of surgery, while some others questioned their surgical approach.
The Court determined that a constitutional protection of a right to free development of personality meant that a child’s autonomy increases with age, including the development of a gender identity and bodily awareness.<ref name= "Holmes2006">{{Cite book| publisher = University of Minnesota Press| pages = 32–50| last = Holmes| first = Morgan| authorlink = Morgan Holmes | title = Transgender Rights| chapter = Deciding fate or protecting a developing autonomy? Intersex children and the Colombian Constitutional Court| location = Minneapolis, Minnesota| date = 2006}}</ref> The Court determined that genital surgeries should not be conducted on children over the age of five. It determined that multidisciplinary teams should assess children’s needs on a case-by-case basis.<ref name="icj">{{Cite web| last = International Commission of Jurists| title = Chapter six: Intersex| accessdate = 2017-02-15| url = http://www.icj.org/sogi-casebook-introduction/chapter-six-intersex/| authorlink = International Commission of Jurists| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161018132719/http://www.icj.org/sogi-casebook-introduction/chapter-six-intersex/| archivedate = 2016-10-18| df = }}</ref><ref name="icj337">{{Cite web| last = International Commission of Jurists| title = Sentencia SU 337/99, Constitutional Court of Colombia (12 May 1999)| accessdate = 2017-02-15| url = https://www.icj.org/sogicasebook/sentencia-su-33799-constitutional-court-of-colombia-12-may-1999/| authorlink = International Commission of Jurists| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170216053942/https://www.icj.org/sogicasebook/sentencia-su-33799-constitutional-court-of-colombia-12-may-1999/| archivedate = 16 February 2017| df = }}</ref><ref name="icj337es">{{cite web | last = International Commission of Jurists | title = Sentencia SU-337/99 | url = https://www.icj.org/wp-content/uploads/1999/05/Sentencia-SU-337-99-Constitutional-Court-of-Colombia-Spanish.pdf | authorlink = International Commission of Jurists | accessdate = 2017-02-15 | language = es | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180104223909/https://www.icj.org/wp-content/uploads/1999/05/Sentencia-SU-337-99-Constitutional-Court-of-Colombia-Spanish.pdf | archivedate = 2018-01-04 | df = }}</ref>
The (now defunct) [[Intersex Society of North America]] stated that the Court decisions "significantly restrict the ability of parents and doctors to resort to the scalpel when children are born with atypical genitals", in a case that was "the first time that a high court anywhere has considered whether [Intersex Genital Mutilation] is a violation of human rights."<ref name="isna">{{cite web | last = Intersex Society of North America | authorlink = Intersex Society of North America | title = COLOMBIA HIGH COURT RESTRICTS INTERSEX GENITAL MUTILATION | date = October 25, 1999 | url = http://www.isna.org/node/181 | accessdate = 2017-02-15 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170216060155/http://www.isna.org/node/181 | archivedate = February 16, 2017 | df = }}</ref> [[Morgan Holmes]] states that, while children who reach the same age and circumstances will be in the same position, then they will "be permitted access to the conditions that protect their autonomies". Other intersex children will not benefit, in particular at the point they are born: "In its worst potential implications and uses, the court's decision may simply amplify the need to expedite procedures".<ref name= "Holmes2006" />
=== Sentencia T-551/99 === In Sentencia T-551/99, later in 1999, the Court ruled in the case of NN, a two-year-old intersex child unable to consent to genital surgeries. Basing a decision on the case of XX, the Court determined that parents could give permission for the normalization of their child's genitals as long as the informed consent was "qualified and persistent." However, this did not exist in the case of NN, because the "parents were led to believe that genital-normalizing surgery was the only option for their daughter. The parents did not examine alternative options to surgery; therefore, their decision did not consider the best interests of the child".<ref name="White2013">{{Cite journal| volume = 37| pages = 777| last = White| first = Ryan L.| title = Preferred Private Parts: Importing Intersex Autonomy for M.C. v. Aaronson| journal = Fordham International Law Journal| url = http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/ilj/vol37/iss3/2| date = 2013| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170323234718/http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/ilj/vol37/iss3/2/| archivedate = 2017-03-23| df = }}</ref>
=== Sentencia T-912/08 === In Sentencia T-912/08, the Court ruled in the case of a five-year old child, ruling that parents and child could give joint consent. In cases where the child and parents had different opinions, no surgery could take place until adulthood.<ref name="icj" />
==Identification documents== {{main|Legal recognition of intersex people}} On June 4, 2015, the Government issued a decree, signed by the Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of the Interior enabling simple administrative changes to legal gender by signing a document before a notary.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/lesterfeder/these-ten-trans-people-just-became-the-first-to-celebrate-co|title=These Ten Trans People Just Got Their First IDs Under Colombia's New Gender Rules|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109023710/https://www.buzzfeed.com/lesterfeder/these-ten-trans-people-just-became-the-first-to-celebrate-co|archivedate=9 November 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/colombia-allows-transgender-community-change-sex-ids-without-physical-exams-1957412|title=Colombia Allows Transgender Community To Change Sex On IDs Without Physical Exams|date=8 June 2015|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815073615/http://www.ibtimes.com/colombia-allows-transgender-community-change-sex-ids-without-physical-exams-1957412|archivedate=15 August 2016|df=}}</ref>

The '''Japan Farmers Party''' ({{lang-ja|日本農民党}}, ''Nihon Nōmintō'') was a [[political party]] in [[Japan]] between 1926 and 1928. It represented a rightist tendency amongst the [[Proletarian parties in Japan, 1925–32|proletarian parties in the country at the time]].<ref name="office"/> The party had a [[nationalist]] orientation.<ref name="sc9"/>
==Split from the Labour-Farmer Party== The party emerged from a split in the [[Labour-Farmer Party]] in 1926. An older generation of leaders of the Japan Peasant Union, such as Okabe Kansuke and Hirano Rikizo, were uncomforatble with the influence of the younger, radical generation in the Japan Peasant Union (who were keen on including leftwing elements in the Labour-Farmer Party), such as [[Ikuo Oyama|Oyama Ikuo]]. Okabe and Hirano's group broke away from the Labour-Farmer Party in March 1926 and on October 17, 1926 they founded the Japan Farmers Party.<ref name="sc9">[[Robert A. Scalapino|Scalapino, Robert A.]]. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=E9mWiAes7s8C&pg=PA331 Democracy and the party movement in prewar Japan]''. 1975. p. 331</ref><ref>Totten, George O. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sm4FAQAAIAAJ Studies on Japan's Social Democratic Parties]''. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1966. p. 409</ref><ref name="p101">Beckmann, George M., and Genji Okubo. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8IarAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA101 The Japanese Communist Party 1922–1945]''. Stanford, Calif: Stanford University Press, 1969. pp. 101–102</ref> The Japan Farmers Party declared itself to be "a party by farmers, for farmers".<ref name="office"/> In this sense the party differentiated itself from the other proletarian parties, which all declared themselves to be based on a worker-peasant class alliance.<ref>University of Chicago. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8EoTAAAAIAAJ Economic Development and Cultural Change]''. [Chicago]: University of Chicago Press, 1952. p. 197</ref>
==1927== The party won four seats in the 1927 prefectural assembly elections of 1927.<ref>Large, Stephen S. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Zog8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA108 Organized Workers and Socialist Politics in Interwar Japan]''. Cambridge [Cambridgeshire]: Cambridge University Press, 1981. p. 124</ref>
==1928 election== As of 1928, the Japan Farmers Party claimed a membership of 70,138. The figure does however appear to be unreliable, compared to the national vote for the party in the elections the same year.<ref>Totten, George O. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sm4FAQAAIAAJ Studies on Japan's Social Democratic Parties]''. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1966. p. 311</ref> The party launched ten candidates in the [[Japanese general election, 1928|1928 Diet election]], whom together mustered 36,491 votes. None of the candidates of the party were elected.<ref name="sca">[[Scalapino, Robert A.]] ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=WrjFsd9S_qIC The Japanese Communist Movement, 1920–1966]''. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1967. p. 33</ref>
==Merger into the Japan Masses Party== In December 1928 the party merged with the [[Proletarian Masses Party]], the [[Japan Labour-Farmer Party]] and four regional political parties, forming the [[Japan Masses Party]].<ref name="office">[[International Labour Office]]. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=BvtlHAj0Y04C&pg=PA114 Industrial Labour in Japan]''. Japanese economic history, 1930–1960, v. 5. New York: Routledge, 2000. pp. 113–114</ref><ref>Beckmann, George M., and Genji Okubo. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8IarAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA173 The Japanese Communist Party 1922–1945]''. Stanford, Calif: Stanford University Press, 1969. p. 173</ref>

{{Other uses|John Urry (disambiguation){{!}}John Urry}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''John Richard Urry''', [[Fellow of the Academy of Social Sciences|FAcSS]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʊər|i}}; June 1, 1946, London – March 18, 2016, Lancaster) [[FAcSS]] was a British sociologist, Professor at [[Lancaster University]]. He is noted for work in the fields of the sociology of tourism and mobility.
He has written books on many other aspects of modern society including the transition away from 'organised capitalism', the sociology of nature and [[environmentalism]], and social theory in general.
==Background== Born in London and educated at the [[Haberdashers' Aske's Boys School]], Urry gained his first degrees from [[Christ's College, Cambridge]] in 1967, a 'double first' BA and [[Master of Arts (Oxbridge and Dublin)|MA]] in Economics, before going on to gain his PhD in Sociology from the same institution in 1972. He arrived at Lancaster University Sociology department as a lecturer in 1970, becoming head of department in 1983 and a professor in 1985.
Urry was a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Arts]], a Founding Academician of the UK [[Academy of Learned Societies for the Social Sciences]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Professor John Urry FAcSS|url=https://www.acss.org.uk/news/professor-john-urry-facss/|website=Academy of Social Sciences|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref> and was a Visiting Professor at both Bristol and Roskilde Geography Departments.
His partner was the sociologist [[Sylvia Walby]].
==Research interests==
His original research interests were in the sociology of power and revolution and this resulted in the publication of ''Reference Groups and the Theory of Revolution'' (1973) and ''Power in Britain'' (1973).
Early work at Lancaster was in the area of social theory and the philosophy of the social sciences. ''Social Theory as Science'', (1975, 1982), co-written with his colleague Russell Keat, set out the main features of the realist philosophy of science. Critical confrontation with a number of [[Marxism|Marxist traditions]], of [[Althusser]]ian [[structuralism]], German state theory, and neo-[[Gramsci]]an theory, resulted in the ''Anatomy of Capitalist Societies'' (1981).
==Research Areas== Research until his death focused on five main areas.
===Regionalism=== First, there was the urban and regional research mainly associated with the Lancaster Regionalism Group. Collaborative research resulted in ''Localities, Class and Gender'' (1985) and ''Restructuring. Place, Class and Gender'' (1990) Two particular themes were pursued: the relationship between society and space (as in the ''Social Relations and Spatial Structures'', co-edited with Derek Gregory, 1985); and the possibilities of developing local economic policies (as in ''Place, Policy and Politics'', 1990).
===Economic and social change=== The second area of research was the more general dimensions of economic and social change in western capitalist societies. This resulted in three jointly written books, ''Capital, Labour and the Middle Classes'' (1983); ''The End of Organized Capitalism'' (1987); and ''Economies of Signs and Space'' (1994; latter two with [[Scott Lash]]).
===Consumer and tourism services=== Thirdly, research focused upon one particular set of industries that are of particular significance in contemporary western societies, namely consumer services and especially tourist-related services. The economic, social, environmental and cultural implications of such developments can be seen in ''The Tourist Gaze'' (1990, 2002: 2nd edn.), ''Consuming Places'' (1995), ''Touring Cultures'' (1997, edited with Chris Rojek), ''Tourism Mobilities'' (2004, edited with Mimi Sheller), and ''Performing Tourist Places'' (with J-O Barenholdt, M Haldrup, J. Larsen). This concern was extended to issues of environmental change and the 'sociology of nature' see ''Contested Natures'' (1998), ''Bodies of Nature'' (2001) (both with Phil Macnaghten) and ''Climate Change and Society'' (2011).
===Mobility=== Fourthly, Urry had various research projects and publications relating to the changing nature of mobility. Publications include: ''Sociology Beyond Societies'' (2000), a special issue of Theory, Culture and Society, (August 2004 on Automobilities coedited with Mike Feathersone, Nigel Thrift); Mobile Technologies of the City (2006); coedited with [[Mimi Sheller]]. John Urry also directed the Centre for Mobilities Research between 2003 and 2015 and was later the Co-Director of the Institute for Social Futures.
===Complexity theory=== Finally, John Urry had been exploring some implications of [[complexity theory for the social sciences]]. Publications here include ''Global Complexity'' (2003), and "Complexity", a special double issue of ''[[Theory, Culture & Society]] ''(2005).
He was also one of the founding editors of the new journal ''[[Mobilities (journal)|Mobilities]]'', and served as editor of the ''International Library of Sociology'' since 1990 (Routledge).

{{Italic title|force=yes}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2009}} The '''''Journal of Community and Applied Social Psychology''''' is a bimonthly [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] that publishes papers dealing with [[social psychology]] and [[community psychology]] in the context of community problems and strengths. The journal is aimed at [[Community development|community practitioners]] and community/social psychology professionals and [[research]]ers. The [[editor-in-chief]] is Flora Cornish ([[London School of Economics|London School of Economics & Political Science]]).
== Readership == The ''Journal of Community and Applied Social Psychology'' is aimed at a readership consisting of social psychologists, [[clinical psychologist]]s, [[social worker]]s, [[Administration (business)|administrator]]s, [[community practitioner]]s, [[health professional]]s, [[social scientist]]s, and [[psychiatrist]]s. The journal is also open to lay members of the community by maintaining a less formal dialog with them through its ''Communications and commentary'' sections.
== Content == The journal publishes: * Research papers * Review articles * Innovations in practice * Communications and commentary * Book and other media reviews * Calendar of events

The {{Nihongo|'''Kakitsu uprising'''|嘉吉の徳政一揆 or 嘉吉の土一揆|Kakitsu no Tokusei Ikki or Kakitsu no Tsuchi Ikki}} was a peasant uprising demanding debt cancellation that occurred in 1441, the 1st year of [[Kakitsu]], in Kyoto and surrounding areas such as [[Ōmi Province]].
== Background == In August, amidst the political chaos following the assassination in June of the 6th shōgun [[Ashikaga Yoshinori]], peasants revolted, with the [[bashaku]] of Kyoto and Sakamoto and Otsu in [[Ōmi Province]] at their core, in demand of a comprehensive debt cancellation order on the basis of "daihajime no tokusei", [[debt relief]] on the occasion of the ascension of a new shōgun. [[Jizamurai]] took the leadership of the movement and it swelled into a revolt of several tens of thousands of people. This insurrection did not spread everywhere, but rather formed a ring around Kyoto.
== Rebellion == After severing communication between Kyoto and the outside world, the rebel army attacked [[sake]] merchants, storehouse money brokers, and [[Buddhist temples in Japan|temples]]. Under the guidance of ji-samurai, the rebel force acted in an organized manner and kept a lid on wanton looting. They occupied [[Tō-ji]] and [[Kitano Tenmangū]] and blockaded Tanbaguchi and Nishihachijou.
At the beginning of the uprising Mitsutsuna Rokkaku, the [[shugo]] of Ōmi Province, issued his debt's cancellation order, but because [[Enryaku-ji]] opposed it, their contracted bashaku of Omi were alienated from the rebels and even opposed them as they went further in occupying [[Kiyomizu-dera]].
While the shogunate at first intended to get a handle on the situation by promulgating a debt relief order for peasants only, the rebels were trying to get the support of members of the establishment by demanding comprehensive debt cancellation at a flat province-wide rate that also included the [[kuge]] and [[Buke (Japan)|buke]]. Furthermore, the [[kanrei]] Mochiyuki Hosokawa had accepted a bribe of 1,000 [[Japanese units of measurement#Money|kanmon]] from the storehouse money brokers before he released an order to dispatch troops for their protection, and the ''[[daimyō]]'' who knew about the bribe refused his order. In the case of the ''daimyō'' Mochikuni Hatakeyama, he opposed the suppression of the uprising because his own vassals were involved in it, and the situation became even more chaotic.
Finally the 7th ''[[shōgun]]'' [[Ashikaga Yoshikatsu]] accepted their demands and issued a comprehensive debt cancellation order, the "Yamashiro Ikkoku Heikin Tokuseirei",<ref>Kato Tomoyasu et al., 日本史総合年表 (Tokyo: Yoshikawa Kōbunkan, 2001), 282.</ref> which included debt from land sold in perpetuity by farmers less than 20 years ago.<ref>Suzanne Marie Gay, The moneylenders of late medieval Kyoto (Honolulu: University of Hawaii Press, 2001), 136.</ref> Because the shogunate released an official debt cancellation order, as opposed to their eventual refusal to do so during the [[Shōchō Uprising]], greatly damaged its authority.

'''Kotjebi''', '''kotchebi''', or '''ggotjebi'''<ref name='AP_2013-06-05'>{{cite news | first = Hyung-Jin | last = Kim | title = Activist: Smiling NKorean defectors told of misery | date = 5 Jun 2013 | publisher = [[Yahoo!]] | url = https://news.yahoo.com/activist-smiling-nkorean-defectors-told-misery-112343717.html | work = [[Associated Press]] | accessdate = 2013-06-05}}</ref> ({{korean|context=north|hangul=[[:wikt:꽃#Korean|꽃]][[:wikt:제비#Korean|제비]]|rr=kkotjebi|mr=kkotchebi}}) is a [[Korean language|Korean]] term denoting [[North Korea]]n [[Street children|homeless children]]. The term literally means "flowering (꽃) [[swallow]]s (제비)", given because of the kotjebi's constant search for food and shelter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cdQ8QZU6H0MC&pg=PT93&lpg=PT93&dq=kotchebi&source=web&ots=qMNU2MUIpU&sig=FKxJPs3I8B0OkFaCnnEyfpyZtjE&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPT93,M1|title=Kim Jong Il's North Korea|work=Google Books|language=|accessdate=2008-08-12}}</ref> The kotjebi are not officially recognized in North Korea, with any mention of the term being prohibited in state publications and documents.<ref name=dailynk>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=3659|title=The Old Generation Calls North Korea "the Great Poverty Country"|work=Dailynk.com|language=|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
== Origins and status ==
The orphaned kotjebi first appeared ''en masse'' in the mid-1990s in the wake of the [[North Korean famine]], which collapsed the food distribution system.<ref name=dailynk /> In an effort to "stabilize the livelihood of vagrants throughout the country", the North Korean government established special "Children's Detention Camps" in 1995, which were effectively rundown apartments. Because of poor conditions in the detention camps children have died of [[malnutrition]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.awomansvoice.org/nl1-2004-2.html |title=Intervention Agenda Item 13: Rights of Children |work=Awomansvoice.org |language= |accessdate=2008-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306003144/http://www.awomansvoice.org/nl1-2004-2.html |archivedate=2012-03-06 |df= }}</ref>
== Livelihood == The kotjebi are constantly forced to seek food and thus gather in groups to [[begging|beg]] and [[pickpocketing|pickpocket]].<ref name=dailynk /> Most of the kotjebi eat only once a day. The diet of the kotjebi, along with the food they obtain from begging, consists mainly of grass soup, wild vegetable porridge, and grass roots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.niew.gov.my/project/DPR_KOREA.pdf|title=DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF KOREA|work=Niew.gov.my|language=|accessdate=2008-08-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66puZMd76?url=http://www.niew.gov.my/project/DPR_KOREA.pdf|archivedate=2012-04-11|df=}}</ref>
